summary: Knees can safely travel past toes when ankle mobility allows — it improves quad activation and maintains balance.
action: Keep heels down, push knees slightly forward over toes, maintain upright chest. Film side angle for review.

summary: The hinge movement should come from the hips, not the lower back. Neutral spine reduces spinal shear forces.
action: Push hips back, slight bend in knees, keep bar close to shins. Engage core before pulling.

summary: Scapular retraction stabilizes shoulders and prevents strain during bench press.
action: Pull shoulder blades together, keep elbows at 45°, and lightly touch chest each rep.

summary: A straight bar path improves shoulder stability and reduces anterior deltoid strain.
action: Start with bar at collarbone, move slightly back as you press, lock out overhead with biceps near ears.

summary: Front knee should track in line with toes to reduce ACL stress and improve balance.
action: Step long enough that front shin stays vertical, drive through heel, keep torso tall.

summary: Medium grip activates lats most efficiently without excessive shoulder stress.
action: Grip slightly wider than shoulders, pull to upper chest, avoid leaning back too far.

summary: Full scapular retraction ensures balanced upper-back development.
action: Start with arms extended, pull elbows back, squeeze shoulder blades together, control return.

summary: Proper tension prevents lumbar sag and improves core stability.
action: Brace abs like taking a punch, tuck hips slightly, maintain straight line from head to heels.

summary: Slight knee bend with straight hips maximizes hamstring stretch while protecting back.
action: Hinge until hamstrings stretch, maintain neutral spine, return with hip drive.

summary: 45° elbow angle improves shoulder health and triceps engagement.
action: Keep elbows tucked slightly, body straight, chest touches ground lightly each rep.

summary: Initiate with scapular depression for safer and more efficient pull-ups.
action: Before pulling, bring shoulders down and back, then drive elbows to ribs.

summary: External rotation of the hips improves glute engagement and knee stability.
action: Slightly point toes outward, push knees out as you descend, squeeze glutes at top.

summary: Slower eccentrics (3–4 seconds) enhance muscle growth by increasing time under tension.
action: Lower weight for 3–4 seconds, control bottom position, and explode up.

summary: Tripod foot contact increases stability during compound lifts.
action: Maintain pressure through heel, big toe, and pinky toe — avoid rocking forward or back.

summary: Proper breathing maintains intra-abdominal pressure and spinal stability.
action: Inhale before descent, brace core, exhale through sticking point.

summary: Neutral pelvis prevents anterior tilt and reduces hip strain.
action: Keep ribs stacked over hips, engage glutes, and avoid arching lower back.

summary: Elbows moving along ribcage enhance lat recruitment.
action: Pull elbows tight to sides, pause briefly, control eccentric.

summary: Explosive hip extension powers the swing — not the arms.
action: Snap hips forward, contract glutes hard, and let kettlebell float to chest height.

summary: Rear-foot elevation changes load distribution and balance mechanics.
action: Keep front foot stable, lower straight down, avoid leaning forward.

summary: Neutral wrist reduces forearm tension and isolates biceps.
action: Keep wrists straight, elbows fixed, full range of motion each rep.

summary: Elbows pinned close to body maximize triceps activation.
action: Avoid swinging arms, control tempo, fully extend without locking elbows.

summary: Core control reduces energy leakage and improves stride efficiency.
action: Engage abs lightly while running, keep posture tall, avoid over-rotation.

summary: Straight wrists prevent joint stress during pressing movements.
action: Stack wrists directly above elbows, avoid bending backward.

summary: External rotation stabilizes shoulders during pulling.
action: Rotate arms slightly outward, keep scapula retracted through the movement.

summary: Raising arms at a 30° angle in the scapular plane activates delts while protecting rotator cuff.
action: Lift arms slightly forward of body, stop at shoulder height, control down slowly.
